content:
This is really quite hard.
I didn't have time to debug my code because it really does take longer than you'd think just to get started with a solution on this.

I ended up winning my clash with 33%!
I think this would be a better clash without the arbitrary characters and maybe without the repeating letters.
https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/4134743919e4772748a622f84321c20d968f5e8

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it, it makes a good clash. The task is not easy, but definitely solvable.

Looks really nice, I'm at the edge of approving it - the only issue I see is that I doubt that this particular task is suitable for the Reverse mode. Maybe it would if there were only letters, no spaces or numbers, but still it would be considered (or at least I would consider this) hard.

Apart from that - good work.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked to solve this problem

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Valid af ðŸ‘Œ

You should precise that two same letters will not break the sequence. 

And that two sequences cannot overlap, otherwise you could have this :

aba => 2-2

Apart from those problems, this is an interesting problem.
Apparently letters are increasing when the following letter is equal. The text suggests that it must be later (and not equal).
Thanks for comment. English is not my native.

Output section

Please change "numbers" to "lengths".
Please change "splited" to "separated".
Please delete "For empty string the answer is 0".


Constraints section

Please add "1 <" in front of the constraint.


Goal section

Suggest to rewrite as follows to be clearer:

Output the lengths of all the sequences of decreasing / increasing letters in the given message.

Letters are <<decreasing>> if one letter is followed by another letter which appears earlier in the alphabet. Letters are <<increasing>> if one letter is followed by another letter which appears later in the alphabet

When a letter is part of a decreasing sequence and an increasing sequence at the same time, it is deemed to belong to the earlier sequence, e.g. acedb consists of an increasing sequence of length 3 and a decreasing sequence of length 2.

Repeating letters are included in the same sequence as if it is just one letter, but we still count all of them, e.g. bbba is a decreasing sequence of length 4, while abb is an increasing sequence of length 3.

Characters that are not letters should be ignored. Letter case is irrelevant.

The lengths should be separated by '-' (minus) and output in a single line, e.g. the output for acedb is 3-2.


Thanks.
In conditions we have: "Repeating letters are included in the same sequence as if it is just one letter, but we still count all of them"
In conditions: "When a letter is part of a decreasing sequence and an increasing sequence at the same time, it is deemed to belong to the earlier sequence,"
I agree about the complexity of Reverse Mode. I didn't intend to enable this mode, apparently I didn't notice it when editing the task.
In conditions we have: "Repeating letters are included in the same sequence as if it is just one letter, but we still count all of them"
